body: This is something to consider when fixing https://github.com/akka/akka-http/issues/1240.

issue.title: Incorrect handling of `filename`, `filename*` in Content-Disposition header

labels.name: 1 - triaged
labels.description: Tickets that are safe to pick up for contributing in terms of likeliness of being accepted

labels.name: t:model
labels.description: Issues around the model classes and its functionality

labels.name: t:core
labels.description: Issues related to the akka-http-core module

repository.name: akka-http
repository.description: The Streaming-first HTTP server/module of Akka

issue.body:
This issue is visible in Play when we're sending a result. Play creates a header value like the following:

```
Content-Disposition: inline; filename="测 试.tmp"; filename*=utf-8''%E6%B5%8B%20%E8%AF%95.tmp
```

Akka HTTP parses this value in Play's `AkkaModelConversion` class, then renders the result as:

```
Content-Disposition: inline; filename="utf-8''%E6%B5%8B%20%E8%AF%95.tmp"
```

I believe this shows that Akka HTTP has bugs in both parsing and rendering the header.

* When parsing the header, the `filename*` parameter is preferred over the `filename`, since it comes second in the parameter list. This is correctly handled. However, the `filename*` has a special prefix (`utf8''`) that specifies the character encoding. This prefix should be used by the parser to set the character encoding, but not included in the filename itself. Akka HTTP appears to be including this value in the filename itself, rather than using it to specify a character set when decoding.

* When rendering the header, the `filename` parameter should probably only include "safe" ISO-8859-1, characters. Unsafe characters that need escaping should probably be stripped out, rather than encoded with `%`, like Akka HTTP does. This is because RFC2616 says that `\` should be used for quoting strings here. To be safe, complex characters could be excluded from the `filename` parameter and encoded properly in the `filename*` parameter instead. Modern clients will recognise and correctly handle the `filename*` parameter, ignoring the `filename` parameter. The `filename*` parameter can include the true filename, encoded and percent-escaped as per RFC6266. The suggested encoding is UTF-8, since it is mandatory for clients to support this encoding.

See:
* Related Play issue: https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7501
* RFC about the filename parameter: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6266#section-4.3
* Example Content-Disposition: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6266#section-5
* RFC about mandatory client encodings: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5987#section-3.2
* How to encode `*` parameters with non-standard characters: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2231#section-4
* How to encode non-`*` parameters: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#section-2.2

issue.title: Provide raw headers when using akka-http backend

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Hello,

I just ran into an issue with Akka HTTP parsing an Authorization header in a weird way, which in my case ended up in experiencing errors because I'm doing authentication delegation by forwarding the header to another service which did not expect this "format".

Akka HTTP seems to provide `RawHeader` instances according to the documentation (http://doc.akka.io/docs/akka-http/10.0.9/scala/http/common/http-model.html#http-headers). It would be nice to have access to those from the Play API for such cases. I'm not sure what would make more sense API-wise though. For now, I'm going to use Netty.

### Play Version (2.5.x / etc)
2.6.3

### API (Scala / Java / Neither / Both)
Scala

body: An example from a user where changing the format causes problems: https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7737#issuecomment-323335828. In this example, parameters are re-ordered, whitespace is stripped, quotes are removed. It would be more conservative if akka-http preserved the original formatting - perhaps by storing the original raw string in the parsed header so it can use that original string when re-rendering the header in the future.

We're also seeing this problem in our Authorization headers. Our spec requires us to return RFC7235 compliant authentication challenge headers which end up having values like: `Bearer realm="http://blah.io/",scope="blah.io",service=""` converted to `Bearer realm="http://blah.io/",scope=blah.io,service=""`.

It seems like only the `scope` field is being modified in our case and `realm` and `service` are left as is.
Tagged as 2.6.8 because this is an Akka HTTP backend related regression that we should fix on the 2.6.x branch.

issue.title: Add setting to control parsing of headers

labels.name: t:server
labels.description: Issues related to the HTTP server

labels.name: t:core
labels.description: Issues related to the akka-http-core module

repository.name: akka-http
repository.description: The Streaming-first HTTP server/module of Akka

issue.body:
In Play 2.6 we switched from Netty to Akka HTTP as the default HTTP backend. This has led to a number of bugs because of the different way that Akka HTTP handles headers compared to Netty. Netty headers are raw string whereas Akka HTTP uses type-safe objects for many headers. These type safe objects are parsed from the underlying header values according to the their specification.

Type-safe headers are a good idea in principle but it runs into problems when:

1. Play users need to send/receive non-spec compliant headers (https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7549)
2. Akka HTTP isn't currently spec-compliant (https://github.com/playframework/playframework/pull/7515, https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7997, https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7501)
3. Akka HTTP is spec compliant, but there is more than one way to be spec compliant and Play users need to send/receive headers in a specific way (https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7737, https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7733, https://github.com/akka/akka-http/issues/966, https://github.com/playframework/playframework/pull/7498)

Akka HTTP does make it possible to use `RawHeader`s. Play uses `RawHeader`s for HTTP responses, but we can't use `RawHeader`s when receiving requests, since the header objects are created internally by Akka HTTP inside the header parsing code.

My suggestion is that we add a new setting to Akka HTTP to give Play (and other users) more control over how HTTP headers are parsed. Here are a few ideas for how a setting could work:

1. A `Boolean` setting that switches Akka HTTP into "raw" mode - all headers are parsed as `RawHeader`s.
2. A `String => Boolean` setting that maps header names to a `Boolean` value, giving more fine-grained control over which headers can be parsed into typed headers and which should be parsed as `RawHeader`s.
3. A `HeaderParser => HeaderParser` (e.g. where `type HeaderParser = (String, String) => Either[ErrorResult, HttpHeader]`) setting that allows the user to override the default `HeaderParser` logic and patch their own logic in. This trivially allows replacing all headers with `ReadHeader`s. Users would also be able to continue to use typed headers and even alter the parsing logic for those headers if they need.

body: Added issue to track this upstream: https://github.com/akka/akka-http/issues/1550

issue.title: Don't parse headers in Akka HTTP

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Fixes #7733,  #7735, #7737 (maybe main issue, definitely `User-Agent` example), #7719, #7997, #8205. Also maybe fixes #8149 (unverified right now).

A recent change to Akka HTTP allows us to disable header parsing. Disabling header parsing, where possible, should fix bugs and improve performance.

This PR is ready now that Akka HTTP 10.0.13 has been released with the following patch: https://github.com/akka/akka-http/pull/1937.

issue.title: [2.6.x]: Change Akka HTTP backend to use raw headers

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Fixes #7733, #7735, #7719, #7997, #8205.

Maybe fixed, but not verified: #7737, #8149.

Most request and response headers are now unparsed by Akka HTTP and stored as RawHeaders. That Akka HTTP won't log warnings, won't reject headers and won't reformat headers.

Several headers are still parsed in order for Akka HTTP to function properly: Content-Type, Content-Encoding, WebSocket related headers, etc. These headers are in a whitelist in the Akka HTTP source.

I was originally going to merge #8296 and then backport it, but we're waiting on a version of Akka HTTP to be ready for the *master* branch, so instead we can merge this to *2.6.x* and then forward port it later.
